marketNews.title: Indonesian Government to Exclude Oil and Gas Exporters from New Foreign Exchange Retention Policy
marketNews.content: Secretary of the Coordinating Ministry for Economic Affairs, Susiwijono Moegiarso, said on Wednesday (22/1) that the government will exempt oil and gas exporters from the new foreign exchange retention policy for export earnings of natural resources (DHE SDA), citing the nature of the sector's business. The statement came after Coordinating Minister for Economic Affairs, Airlangga Hartarto, said on Tuesday (21/1) that the government will revise the DHE SDA placement rule to a minimum of 100 percent for one year, which is higher and longer than the existing rule of a minimum of 30 percent for three months. It is not yet known whether Susiwijono's comment implies that oil and gas exporters will still be required to meet the current minimum 30 percent DHE SDA requirement.

marketNews.title: Indonesia Revises DHE SDA Placement Rule to Minimum 100% for One Year
marketNews.content: Coordinating Minister for Economic Affairs, Airlangga Hartarto, announced on Tuesday (21/1) that the government will revise the DHE SDA placement regulation to a minimum of 100 percent for a period of one year, which is larger and longer than the existing rule that requires a minimum of 30 percent for three months.

marketNews.title: ExxonMobil Indonesia Signs MOU for Carbon Capture and Storage and Petrochemical Plant
marketNews.content: Minister for Coordinating Economic Affairs, Airlangga Hartarto, said on Wednesday (22/1) that ExxonMobil Indonesia has officially signed a memorandum of understanding with the government to develop a carbon capture and storage (CCS) project and a petrochemical plant. The initial investment for the CCS project is estimated at 10 billion US dollars, with a total long-term commitment of 15 billion US dollars. Deputy Minister Elen Setiadi added that the CCS facility will be built around the Sunda-Asri Strait and is designed to store up to 3 gigatonnes of carbon per year. The petrochemical plant's exact location is still under survey, as it requires about 500 hectares of land within 100 kilometres of the CCS facility.

marketNews.title: Apple Nears Deal to Lift Indonesian iPhone Ban
marketNews.content: Minister of Investment and Inward Investment, Rosan Roeslani, told Bloomberg on Tuesday (21/1) that the government is close to reaching an agreement with Apple Inc. (NASDAQ: AAPL) regarding an investment that would lift the ban on selling the iPhone 16 in Indonesia. Rosan said the deal is expected to be finalized within one to two weeks. The statement followed remarks by the Minister of Industry, Agus Gumiwang Kartasasmita, who had earlier in January rejected a 1-billion-dollar investment offer from Apple to build an AirTag factory and develop a developer academy in Indonesia, urging Apple to establish an iPhone component plant to obtain a domestic component certificate (TKDN), a prerequisite for iPhone sales in the country.

marketNews.title: Google Fined 202.5 Billion Rupiah by KPPU for Unfair Practices
marketNews.content: The Indonesian Competition Commission (KPPU) ordered Google to pay a fine of 202.5 billion rupiah on Tuesday (21/1) for unfair business practices related to its payment system for Google Play Store. The decision follows a KPPU investigation that began in 2022, which found that Google forced app developers in Indonesia to use Google Play Billing, which charges higher rates than other payment systems, and threatened to remove apps that did not comply. The commission also found that Google imposed fees of up to 30 percent through Google Play Billing. A Google spokesperson said on Wednesday (22/1) that the company will appeal the ruling.

marketNews.title: Bloomberg Reports eFishery Inflated Revenue by $600 Million
marketNews.content: Bloomberg reported on Tuesday (21/1) that an early investigation into eFishery's financial statements estimates that the agritech start-up inflated its revenue by almost 600 million US dollars during the nine months ended December 2024, increasing reported revenue from 157 million to 752 million dollars. The probe, supported by investors including SoftBank Group Corp. and Temasek Holdings Pte., also found that the company posted a net loss of 35.4 million dollars for the same period, compared with a net profit of 16 million dollars disclosed to investors. Bloomberg noted that the figures may change as the investigation continues. Former CEO and co-founder Gibran Huzaifah has not responded to Bloomberg's request for comment.

marketNews.title: Indonesia Continues Gas Price Incentive (HGBT) Despite Pending Regulation
marketNews.content: Coordinating Minister for Economic Affairs, Airlangga Hartarto, confirmed on Tuesday (21/1) that the specific natural gas price incentive (HGBT) will be continued, although the official regulation will be announced later. Airlangga did not specify which industrial sectors will receive the incentive. Earlier, the Minister of Energy and Mineral Resources, Bahlil Lahadalia, said in early January that the government was discussing a possible reduction in the number of HGBT recipients, particularly for companies that have recorded a strong internal rate of return.

marketNews.title: Indonesia to Sign MoU with UAE for 1 Million Housing Units
marketNews.content: The head of the Housing Task Force and brother of President Prabowo Subianto, Hashim Djojohadikusumo, said on Tuesday (21/1) that the government will sign a memorandum of understanding with the United Arab Emirates to provide 1 million housing units by the end of January 2025. He also disclosed that investors from Turkey and Singapore are each interested in building 500,000 and 100,000 units respectively. The housing construction is part of a government program targeting 3 million homes per year. Hashim also revealed that Qatar's investment for the 1 million units, announced earlier, is estimated at 16-20 billion US dollars.

tickerNews.title: BBNI FY24: Net Profit +2.7% YoY, Below Expectations
tickerNews.content: Bank Negara Indonesia (BBNI) reported a net profit of 5.2 trillion rupiah for the fourth quarter of 2024, a decrease of 8.2 percent quarter-on-quarter and unchanged year-on-year. This resulted in a full-year 2024 net profit of 21.5 trillion rupiah, a growth of 2.7 percent year-on-year, slightly below expectations at 97.2 percent of the consensus FY24 forecast. The positive performance was driven by (1) a solid Net Interest Margin (NIM); (2) controlled credit cost (CoC) and stable asset quality; and (3) strong loan growth despite liquidity challenges. NIM for the bank only rose to 4.5 percent in Q4 2024, putting the FY24 average at 4.2 percent, above the FY24 guidance of over 4 percent. The increase was supported by Rural Business Credit (KUR) lending; excluding KUR, core NIM was 4.2 percent in Q4. Loan yield for the bank only rose about 20 basis points quarter-on-quarter, while cost of funds rose 5 basis points due to higher CASA and deposit rates. Management targets a FY25 NIM of 4-4.2 percent, expecting weakness in the first half of 2025 before improvement in the second half, based on tighter liquidity projections for H1 2025. Credit cost (CoC) for the bank only expanded to 1.5 percent in Q4 2024, though it remained at 1.1 percent for the full year, aligning with the FY24 guidance of plus or minus 1 percent. The increase was caused by additional provisions for the Sri Rejeki Isman group (SRIL) and a conservative approach to the micro-SME segment. Asset quality improved, with Loan at Risk (LAR) falling to 10.3 percent and gross non-performing loans staying at 2 percent. Management targets a FY25 CoC of around plus or minus 1 percent. Loan growth for FY24 was 11.6 percent year-on-year, matching the FY24 guidance range of 10-12 percent, driven by a 17.6 percent increase in corporate loans while the KUR segment contracted 25 percent year-on-year. Liquidity tightened, with the loan-to-deposit ratio rising to 96.1 percent in FY24 from 85.8 percent in FY23. Despite a reduction in the Bank Indonesia policy rate, liquidity challenges persist, but management expects improvement through (1) CASA growth via the Wondr app; (2) the latest DHE SDA revision; and (3) higher mandatory giro balances. Credit growth for FY25 is targeted at 8-10 percent, below the Bank Indonesia banking sector target of 11-13 percent. The dividend payout ratio for FY24 is planned at 50-60 percent, implying a dividend yield of 6-7.2 percent based on the Wednesday (22/1) closing price of 4,790 rupiah per share.

tickerNews.title: BVIC Clarifies Value of Bank Victoria Syariah Divestment
tickerNews.content: Bank Victoria International (BVIC) clarified to the IDX that the report by Bisnis on 20 January 2025 stating that the transaction value of the divestment of PT Bank Victoria Syariah to Bank Tabungan Negara (BBTN) was 1.06 trillion rupiah was incorrect. BVIC explained that the figure represented only the nominal value of all shares of PT Bank Victoria Syariah, which issued 1.06 billion shares with a nominal price of 1,000 rupiah each. The actual transaction value will be disclosed after the transaction plan is completed. Previously, BBTN CEO Nixon L.P. Napitupulu said on Tuesday (21/1) that the acquisition value was below 1.5 times its book value and that BBTN would acquire Bank Victoria Syariah in a "empty" condition, leaving only equity and state securities, with credit and third-party funds returning to the owners.

tickerNews.title: BBRI CEO Sunarso Purchases 210,000 Shares
tickerNews.content: Bank Rakyat Indonesia (BBRI) CEO Sunarso bought 210,000 BBRI shares at an average price of 4,200 rupiah per share on 16 January 2025. The total transaction value was approximately 882 million rupiah. After the transaction, Sunarso's ownership in BBRI increased from 0.0037 percent to 0.0039 percent.

tickerNews.title: Saratoga Investama Sedaya Plans IPOs for Portfolio Companies
tickerNews.content: Saratoga Investama Sedaya (SRTG) Investment Director Devin Wirawan said the firm is opening opportunities to conduct IPOs on the IDX for companies in its portfolio that are currently private. The companies include cold-chain logistics provider MGM Bosco Logistics, solar energy company Xurya Energi, Zap care clinics, and Brawijaya Hospitals. Devin stated that SRTG aims for at least one portfolio company to contribute a net asset value (NAV) of 1 billion US dollars. He also noted that SRTG has increased its NAV three-fold over the past six years to reach 56 trillion rupiah.

tickerNews.title: Satria Antaran Tbk Shareholder Purchases 16.8 Million Shares
tickerNews.content: Satria Antaran Tbk (SRAJ) controlling shareholder and commissioner Jonathan Tahir bought approximately 16.8 million SRAJ shares at an average price of 1,880 rupiah per share on 14 January 2025, a discount of 19.7 percent to the closing price on the same day. The total transaction value was about 31.6 billion rupiah. After the transaction, Jonathan Tahir's direct ownership increased from 0.49 percent to 0.63 percent.

tickerNews.title: Semen Indonesia Reports Decline in Cement Sales
tickerNews.content: Semen Indonesia (SMGR) recorded a decline in cement sales volume to 3.1 million tonnes in December 2024, down 18 percent year-on-year and 12 percent month-on-month, worse than the industry-wide decline (excluding Semen Grobogan) of 14 percent year-on-year. The 4Q 2024 sales volume fell to 10.3 million tonnes, a 10 percent year-on-year decrease but a 0.6 percent quarter-on-quarter increase. Total 2024 sales were 38 million tonnes, down 6 percent year-on-year. The December decline was driven by a reduction in sales from Indonesian facilities to 3 million tonnes, an 18 percent year-on-year and 13 percent month-on-month drop. Bagged cement accounted for 69.5 percent of December 2024 sales (vs. 68.5 percent in November 2024) and 69.8 percent for the full year 2024.

tickerNews.title: Satyamitra Kemas Lestari Forms Joint Venture with Guangzhou Yi Song Paper Products
tickerNews.content: Satyamitra Kemas Lestari (SMKL) announced a partnership with Guangzhou Yi Song Paper Products Company Ltd. to establish a joint venture named PT Satyamitra Yisong Indonesia, which will operate in the packaging and paper box industry. The joint venture will develop and market paper mold products in Indonesia, aiming to replace styrofoam containers. The joint venture was founded with a authorized capital of 30 billion rupiah, with SMKL holding a 60 percent stake.

tickerNews.title: DRMA Shareholder Noel Aelyo Laras Kusuma Negara Executes Two Transactions
tickerNews.content: DRMA commissioner Noel Aelyo Laras Kusuma Negara bought 150,000 DRMA shares at an average price of 925 rupiah per share on 20 January 2025, totaling approximately 139 million rupiah. Three days earlier, he sold 500,000 DRMA shares at an average price of 915 rupiah per share, totaling about 457 million rupiah. After both transactions, his ownership decreased from 1.434 percent to 1.426 percent.

tickerNews.title: Logisticsplus International Sells Approximately 304 Million LOPI Shares
tickerNews.content: Logisticsplus International, the shareholder of Logisticplus International (LOPI), sold approximately 304 million LOPI shares at an average price of 39 rupiah per share on 17 January 2025. The total transaction value was about 11.9 billion rupiah and was intended for consolidating majority ownership. After the transaction, Logisticsplus International's ownership in LOPI fell from 27.64 percent to zero.
